references: TableÂ I displays the top-1 test accuracy of different approaches on four datasets. The hyperparameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu in FedIntR, MOONÂ [8], FedProxÂ [5], and FedCKAÂ [9] can be tuned to control the regularization strength in the local training loss. For each approach, we tune the Î¼ğœ‡\mu value and report the best results. For FedIntR and FedCKA, we tune Î¼ğœ‡\mu from [0.1,1,3,5,10]0.113510[0.1,1,3,5,10] (which covers the range used by the original FedCKA paper). We tune Î¼ğœ‡\mu from [0.1,1,5,10]0.11510[0.1,1,5,10] for MOON and [0.001,0.01,0.1,1]0.0010.010.11[0.001,0.01,0.1,1] for FedProx, according to their respective papers. \hlineB3 Î¼ğœ‡\mu Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 CIFAR-100

references: Our proposed FedIntR framework achieves superior performance in the SVHN and CIFAR-10 datasets compared to the baseline techniques. For the Fashion-MNIST dataset, both FedIntR and MOON achieve the best performance. FedCKA outperforms FedIntR on the CIFAR-100 dataset, but FedIntR still maintains a comparable performance. There are three plausible explanations for this. (i) For the CIFAR-100 dataset, we employ the ResNet-20 model, which contains fewer number of extraction points for intermediate representations than the CNN model. (ii) The superior performance of FedIntR can be observed more clearly with a higher degree of data heterogeneity, which will be discussed in SectionÂ IV-C, where we compare the performance of different techniques on varying degrees of data heterogeneity. (iii) FedIntR is more beneficial from longer training. By default, we set the number of communication rounds as 100, but as we will discuss in SectionÂ IV-D, FedIntR performs better with a higher number of training rounds. For reference, we also provide the performance of FedIntR from tuning Î¼ğœ‡\mu in TableÂ II.

\hlineB3
references: TableÂ III displays the test accuracy values attained by different approaches on the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets with Î²ğ›½\beta values of 5, 0.5, and 0.1. Similar to SectionÂ IV-B, we tune the Î¼ğœ‡\mu value for each approach (shown in parentheses in TableÂ III) and report the best results. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, FedIntR exhibits superior performance over the baseline approaches in all data heterogeneity settings. FedProx has comparable performance to FedIntR when Î²=5ğ›½5\beta=5 (i.e., when the degree of data heterogeneity among the clients is low), but its performance diminishes with a smaller Î²ğ›½\beta value. For the CIFAR-100 dataset, vanilla FedAvg outperforms all other approaches when Î²=5ğ›½5\beta=5. However, as the Î²ğ›½\beta value decreases, incorporating a form of regularization into the local loss can outperform the vanilla FedAvg. With Î²=0.1ğ›½0.1\beta=0.1, our proposed FedIntR significantly outperforms the other approaches. We speculate that fine-grained regularization computed from intermediate representations and layer-wise contributions makes FedIntR more robust in FL environments with high degrees of data heterogeneity.

references: From TableÂ IV, we can observe that vanilla FedAvg outperforms the majority of other approaches in the early training rounds (i.e., T=100ğ‘‡100T=100 and T=200ğ‘‡200T=200) for both N=50ğ‘50N=50 and N=100ğ‘100N=100 settings. This is due to the fact that the local training loss in FedAvg focuses only on performance improvement, whereas the other approaches include a regularization term with additional objectives. However, with a sufficient number of training rounds, FedIntR with Î¼=10ğœ‡10\mu=10 can significantly outperform all other approaches. In the N=50ğ‘50N=50 setting, FedIntR (Î¼=10ğœ‡10\mu=10) outperforms the second best approach, FedProx, by 1.19% at T=800ğ‘‡800T=800, and in the N=100ğ‘100N=100 setting, it outperforms MOON (Î¼=10ğœ‡10\mu=10) by 1.45% at T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000. Fig.Â 4 shows the test accuracy values of different methods in each round for the N=100ğ‘100N=100 setting.

references: In TableÂ V, we compare the performance of FedIntR with and without Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} on four datasets. We can observe that calculating a layer-wise weight Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} for its corresponding representation loss â„“ksubscriptâ„“ğ‘˜\ell_{k} can significantly improve the performance of the resulting global model. Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} determines the contribution of individual â„“ksubscriptâ„“ğ‘˜\ell_{k} to the regularization term, enabling FedIntR to perform local training with fine-grained regularization.
